Definition: Classify the given comment into threat and non-threat. Threat means someone will be hurt or harmed.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: He should be executed, not given 48 years.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment conveys a violent threat to someone.

It would be very sad if pets were killed, but ultimately it is the owner's responsibility to make sure their pets are not out killing birds.

Years ago some Vermont acquaintances got one warning from the Ranger: Next time I see your dog running deer, I'll shoot it. Next time she saw it running deer, she did. 

Vermont does not pretend that trapping, neutering, and releasing dogs solves any problems. They are serious about threats. We just want to feel good about ourselves. If we were serious about feral cats, we would kill them. Neutered cats eat birds. Don't release them. Kill them.

Comment: "...shut it down and die."

Most Catholics don't even know what the Curia is, much less know who is in that institution or group; but you want it dismantled. Maybe replace it with global representatives from the 150 or so National Conferences of Bishops representing 1.2 billion Catholics? I don't know. I haven't the answer except that it will take a long time to dismantle the Curia -- to make the unrigging successful. Bishops can do it by asserting themselves as individual national bodies, but that seems unlikely right now. Some National Conferences of Bishops, of course, are more progressive than others. In the meantime, in dealing with abuse in churches (and everywhere, really), the best route (for bringing about reform) seems to be through local civil courts, sympathetic laypeople and clerics, the press, and Pope Francis. If courts jailed a few bishops, that might help a lot, too.

Comment: I have been involved with Scouting since Cub Scouts. I made Eagle at 13. 45+ years later, I am still part of the organization.

Cub Scouts did not remove this young man from his Webelos Den, his Den Leader did. Generally, the Cubmaster and the Chartering Organization Representative are involved in this process as membership issues are decided by those two positions. Neither the local BSA Council office nor the BSA National office make membership determinations. Unless there is more to the story than is being reported, the Webelos Den Leader did not follow the proper protocol to remove a member from the Cub Scout Pack.

BSA encourages its members to engage in politics at all levels. We encourage our youth to study and understand the issues. We expect the adult leaders to be encouraging and non-judgmental despite their personal views. We are supposed to encourage differing views and the free exchange of beliefs. I have taken Scouts to visit politicians; I love it when the hard questions.

Comment: Comments from GR (CAN)’s chairwoman Helen Chang about pumping water into the wetland from the canal demonstrates how little this company understands about the land they purchased. The wetlands are part of a slough forest complex that is a prime breeding ground for amphibians. Pumping water full of fish into areas of slough forest and vernal pools, where no fish currently exists, means disaster for the existing breeding amphibians as the fish will eat their eggs. She also clearly doesn't understand that it is normal for vernal pools and portions of other wetlands to dry up in late summer. This makes these areas bad habitat for fish and prime habitat for salamanders, frogs and toads whose young have developed by then and moved to land. What will dry up and degrade the slough forest is developing every inch around them and getting rid of the adjoining rich meadowland that support many of the slough forest's bird, bat and reptile species who need both habitats. Save this important wetland.

Comment: The author needs to look a bit harder.  Instead of looking at career politicians, he should look at the broader population.

Jill Stein's support is up around 5% in the national polls (5 x more than the Greens normally earn).  As Jill's policies are more or less identical to Bernie's, I think it's a safe bet that almost all of her supporters would have voted Democrat, if the Democrats had chosen Sanders.  I think we can safely put that 5% down as #NeverClinton Progressives.  

Gary Johnson is doing even better (around 10% - 10 x more than the Libertarians normally earn) and while he's drawing support from Republicans who believe he represents their values a lot better than Trump does, it's also clear from the four-candidate polls that he is pulling his fair share of voters (#NeverClinton Democrats?) from Clinton as well.

#NeverClinton Democrats exist.  Its just a question of whether there are enough of them - and #NeverTrump Republicans - to make a difference.

Comment: I am greatly heartened by the outrage and animosity that the Black Lives Matter movement is inspiring.  In the manner of a negative sign, it strongly suggests that BLM is well positioned  and equipped to accomplish good and significant things. 

The larger society has shown itself more than able to ignore most aspects of  Black American experience, but in their initial focus on unjust policing, BLM has struck a nerve,  and thereby initiated necessary discussion, and, hopefully, positive change. 

There are those among us who will refuse to hear any murmur of discontent from Black communities, without blaming Blacks themselves for whatever ails them. It's a sort of reflex, apparently. Some people will perhaps never accept a Black critique of the social order, or even grant that such a critique might spring from a legitimate source of discontent. Such refusal is, by nature, an expression of contempt, and of-a-piece with structural injustice.  Or so it seems to me.

Comment: I was going to mention King Christian, too.  From what I have read in recent years, it would seem that the story that he appeared on the streets of Denmark wearing the Star of David may be apocryphal.  Still, I think the story is apt. Many years ago, I heard this story recounted in a Christmas homily.  The homilist suggested that what King Christian had done in willingly taking on the Star of David, uniting himself to the Jewish citizens of his kingdom, was precisely an act inspired by the Incarnation of the Son of God, who willingly took on our humanity. It was a memorable homily -- I'm recounting it from the distance of more than thirty years; and no one suggested that King Christian's act of solidarity was anything less than radically, profoundly Christian.
So, too, any act of solidarity we Christian might devise or perform to resist a Muslim registry.
I think that there will also be Jews who will likewise resist this evil.

Comment: Jill Pinkerton, you talked to whomever you talked to. Fine. But abortion in itself is neither a good nor a bad action. It all depends on the interpretation of the pregnant woman. It can be a very bad decision to refrain from abortion in certain circumstances.

Nor is it persuasive to describe abortion as "the killing of a human being." Yes, it is the killing of a certain kind of being who is certainly human. But it is always misleading at best, more usually just plain wrong, to speak of a "human being," as though this were an independent being such as a human infant. There is always a woman attached to that being, and it is always wrong to speak of that being without giving due regard to the necessary presence of the woman.

I too was adopted, from a Catholic agency run by nuns, at age 2 months. And I am firmly in favor of abortion rights for women. There is no other just or humane option.

Comment: "Seniors love Medicare?" LOL
The ones in nursing homes don't: Medicare only covers 100 days of nursing home care.
.
The ones asking for long-term care sure don't "love" it:  It's not covered.
.
The ones seeking custodial care sure don't:  only 1 in 5 are "allowed" to be covered, since one must demonstrate they have little to no income or assets to qualify for that little reward.
.
The ones seeking home-based care sure don't: It is all but impossible to get Medicare to allow it, and home care providers don’t much like this benefit either: since the government (once again) imposes their own cost pricing, providers don’t make much money on it, and under new Medicare rules, they can actually lose money providing such care.
.
The ones seeking vision, hearing, and dental coverage sure don't love it:  Most of these services aren't covered, as well as countless lifesaving drugs under Medicare Part D.
.
http://www.medicareadvocacy.org/the-promise-and-failure-of-medicare-home-health-coverage/

Comment: Fist, I congratulate Sato on winning the 500. I've lived in the Indianapolis area for over 50 years and have attended the 500 race 10 times.  The race is sometimes broadcasted locally as the "Annual Memorial Day Race".  The opening ceremonies begin with a invocation usually given by the Archbishop of the Catholic Archdioceses of Indianapolis in memory of our fallen military. There is a military honor guard ceremony in specific honor of Memorial day that concludes with Taps and an Air Force aircraft flyover in the missing man formation.  God Bless America and the National Anthem are performed.  In 1975 I marched with other Vietnam era vets in the 500 festival parade.  Does this speak to the significance between the 500 race and Memorial Day?  I don't know if you ever served in the military, but veterans remember and honor our fallen brothers and sisters.  I think this backdrop contributed to Frei's imprudent remark.  I don't think he should have been fired.

Comment: When I first lived in Alaska in the 1970's I heard stories of the horror of the change from being a Russian Territory to an American Territory in 1868. The Russians from their capitol of Sitka had created through decades a form of law and order in the territory. Russian ships were making new and longer trade routes to the south. The Russians went on planning despite the politics.  In 1868 with the AK Purchase The Russians were given a choice to stay or go back. Many of the Russians who did stayed later scrambled to leave as law and order ended. The territory was now in total chaos. Mobs and gangs ruled and many innocent people died at their hands. Law came to the territory finally when the representatives in the AK territory pled their case to the US Congress and Union troops from the territory of WA state were sent to restore law and order. I asked why a Union Soldier from the Civil War era was buried in Alaska and that is what I was told.

Comment: If our desire is ultimately to improve mental health outcomes for consumers we need to take a step back and ask the key question: what are the problems and what are some possible solutions to fix them? Proponents describe the need to improve access to mental health care without making the important distinction that access to mental health care does not mean access to psychotropic medications. We need to address systemic issues that favor more aggressive medicine over less intensive interventions when the latter have been shown to be as effective, less costly, and safer (i.e., no side effects that compromise somatic health). There is no reason to assume that prescribing psychologists won’t succumb to the same market pressures that have led most psychiatrists to abandon therapy in lieu of becoming psychopharmacologists. Linda & McGrath (2017) found that 2/3 of prescribing psychologists reported increased income. Is this about improving care or making more money?

Comment: That's a regulation, which is part of regulatory capture, which only exists due to... wait for it... the restrictive licensing.

If it is driver safety, drivers will put them in themselves, or not (which is solely the business of them and perhaps their insurer). If passenger safety, passengers will demand them, or not, based on their own assessment of risk.

Comment: Absolutely agreed.

Both assault and sexual assault see some common issues that work directly against getting convictions.  In both crimes, alcohol is involved in a gross majority of the cases, undermining the quality of testimony, substantially. In both crimes, the vast majority produce no corroborating physical evidence because there's no injuries. 98% of all sexual assaults reported last year had no injuries (type 1), for example. In addition, there's 3rd party witnesses in only a small fraction of the cases for both crimes.  There's generally slightly better chances for witnesses and visible injuries with assault, so the conviction rate is slightly higher, on average, but neither crime sees greater than half of the court cases get a guilty verdict.

Comment: Have you actually looked at Eugene's Zero Vision draft? It's pretty clear that the focus is to make it less likely that motorists will die at the hands of other motorists. This is because their "data", which is heavily biased towards injured motorists, indicates that the majority of roadway injuries and deaths in Eugene are motorist on motorist and that this type is increasing.

It's no big surprise that motorist-only traffic violence is increasing in Eugene. We have lost huge numbers of pedestrians, bus riders and cyclists back to their car seats over the past decade. Walking to work is down almost 30% from its peak, riding the bus is down over 50% and cycling is down over 40%. We're simply running out of soft targets and now have to settle for harder ones.

If implemented as drafted, Eugene's Zero Vision will contribute to our unprecedented loss of active transportation participation. It's another opportunity to live up to our fantastic potential squandered by the Jon Ruiz gang.

Comment: Actually, it was Manitoba Premier John Bracken who moved over to the Conservatives and assumed leadership on the condition that Progressive be added to the name.

The majority of former Progressive Party members joined the Liberals and a smaller number went to the CCF. They were very pro-market, pro free trade oriented - unlike the Conservative Party and National Policy. Progressive related to their economic liberalism oriented views - that is - anti-National Policy. Traditional Liberals viewed them as quite radical rather than moderate. 

In W.L. Morton's book on the Progressive Party, he notes that at a provincial level, many Progressives were drawn to the Social Credit movement (and, ultimately, the Reform movement).

Comment: When confronted by one of his blatant falsehoods, Trump often doesn’t even attempt to back up what he said. He’ll simply reply that “many people say I’m right,” effectively denying the validity of what is usually known as “facts.” The president is responding to a claim of fact not by denying the fact, but by denying the claim that facts are supposed to have on an argument. “He isn’t telling (his opponent) that he’s got his facts wrong. He’s saying that as far as he is concerned facts, as most people understand the term, don’t matter. That they are indistinguishable from, and interchangeable with, opinion, and that statements of fact needn’t have any purchase against a man who is either sufficiently powerful to ignore them or sufficiently shameless to deny them – or, in his case, both.”Bret Stephen’s editor and columnist at the Wall Street Journal

Comment: I'm fortunate to be in good health, as are most Canadians. But there are those among us who aren't so fortunate. Fate has condemned them to a life of perpetual suffering, the likes of which few of us can comprehend.

Assisted dying is not, and must not be a privilege we only give to people who will soon die anyway. There's little mercy or merit in that. Rather, under the Canadian constitution, assisted dying is a right that any severely afflicted Canadian may claim if they fall under the Supreme Court's humane guidelines.

A nation ennobles itself by empowering those who are most afflicted. Assisted dying  grants an individual a measure of control over a life that has otherwise left them helpless and without recourse.

Comment: We retired last summer to Arizona. My wife taught 25 years for ASD. Moving here, we were shocked how little Arizona pays teachers, and offers even less respect. The governor here declared in his state of state address, that they were going to give teachers a huge raise. He said look for our budget announcement the same week. The announcement was made as promised. The raise? It was 4/10ths of one percent. Teachers were insulted. After negative feedback they are considering a $5000 raise. Even with that raise, teachers in Arizona will still be around 49th in pay nationwide. And they will only give the raise if voters approve an additional sales tax. We have thousands of vacant positions here that will never be filled. Class sizes are 40 or more. Some districts can't give any raises, so they offer a 4 day school week as an enticement. 
Why Alaska's politicians and educrats at the school district offices don't get it is surprising. Learn from other states mistakes. Before it's too late.

Comment: The most likely reason is that it is not comfortable for Western journalists to report from these places.

Just before Christmas 1980 I was in Kano, Nigeria when the Maitatsine riots broke out. For days the second largest city in Africa's most populous countries was convulsed. The official death toll was over 4,000 and this was likely low. There were arrows flying in the lorry park. The Nigerian Air Force was making supersonic runs on the old city where Maitatsine's followers were holed up. There were no stories in the international press.

Comment: jgd asks: "How much do you think it will cost to insure the 330 million individuals currently living in the US?"
That depends on whether or not we keep for-profit insurance companies in the loop to skim off 25 to 30 percent in overhead to fill their corporate coffers. Obviously, if we instituted Medicare for all, our taxes would go up to pay for the rest of "the 330 million individuals currently living in the US." That's how most other industrialized nations do it, and their overall healthcare costs are about half of ours.
If we can eliminate or reduce insurance company overhead, it's possible that we would pay less for additional taxes than what we are now paying in insurance premiums, co-pays, deductibles, services not covered, ambulance fees, etc.
With friends in Denmark, we figured that the tax they pay into their national healthcare fund is about half of what we pay just for the premiums. And they have no administrative red tape ... just go in, get care, and go home. Simple.

Comment: The article doesn't indicate how the pilot study would be measured.  The universal income (UI) plans advocated by award winning economists like Milton Friedman mean for it to by universal, and to replace the myriad of situation tested social safeties (welfare, EI, OAS, etc).  These little means-tested safety nets need expensive oversight and leaves gaps.  Find a job, and you lose benefits and risk falling in the cracks if it doesn't work out.  The big UI net allows people to take economic risks.  Every dollar you earn moves you ahead, minus tax of course.  

The question is whether the economic mobility benefits and reduced bureaucratic costs outway the cost of incentivizing some existing marginal workers to work less and scrape by on the dole.

The announced study is means tested, so it is just another small net, and it doesn't seem it will answer that question.

Comment: That has been explained in the ADN in the past, even if it was only piecemeal. Anchorage has been permitting taxis since at least the 1950s. I'm not 100% sure, but I think the current system dates to the mid 1970s. There were two key factors. One was unification: before that, the city, borough and airport all had separate permitting schemes and different regulatory standards. If not for the fact that APD provided police services to the borough's Spenard police service area, things would have been a lot more convoluted. The second key factor dating to the mid 1970s is the fact that persons with stroke in the community started investing in the taxi business when the pipeline construction caused the business to suddenly become a rather lucrative venture. Near as I can tell, taxi permits were open-entry at one point a long time ago. That doesn't help someone who entered the game looking for an investment but weren't necessarily looking to be more actively involved.

Comment: Symptoms of Narcissistic Personality Disorder
The definition of NPD states that it comprises of a persistent manner of grandiosity, a continuous desire for admiration, along with a lack of empathy. It starts by early adulthood and occurs in a range of situations, as signified by the existence of any 5 of the next 9 standards (American Psychiatric Association, 2013):
A grandiose logic of self-importance
A fixation with fantasies of infinite success, control, brilliance, beauty, or idyllic love
A credence that he or she is extraordinary and exceptional and can only be understood by, or should connect with, other extraordinary or important people or institutions
A desire for unwarranted admiration
A sense of entitlement
Interpersonally oppressive behavior
No form of empathy
Resentment of others or a conviction that others are resentful of him or her
A display of egotistical and conceited behaviors or attitudes

DSM 5

Comment: Until high level nuclear waste can safely be disposed of (perhaps by launching it into our local star, often referred to as The Sun), nuclear power's lasting dangerous residue makes it a poor choice as an energy source.   Democratic Senator Reid, while Majority Leader of the Senate, defunded the multi-billion dollar storage site in Nevada in 2010 supposedly for that very reason.  Japan has closed every nuclear power plant which used to provide 30% of Japan's power.  Europe's nuclear energy programs are in a mixed stage of new proposals which are over budget, decommissioning and upgrades of existing plants.  They have yet to come up with a safe disposal location for high level waste.  They are talking about sending low-level waste (like that sent to Yucca Mountain Nevada in 2014) to somewhere in Eastern Europe.   When you have things that are going to be dangerous for  15.7 million years (Iodine-129) or  two million years (Neptunium-237) being optimistic is not an option.

Comment: Good piece Mr. Wohlforth! 
I grew up in a small town in California which was deemed too small to have a high school but had elementary schools. The solution was to bus the older kids 10 miles away for high school. 
Perhaps with some creative thinking some villages could be tied together in this way for the common good. Of course school buses would not work. But I read someplace about other northern communities using hovercraft to transport kids back and forth to schools on frozen or unfrozen river systems. Hovercraft are not that complex and a fleet could be built in Alaska if they could not be acquired cheaply outside. By closing a few schools and sending kids upriver for the day to a full high school like those enjoyed in the city everyone involved gets a better shot a good education. And they can still live in their ancestral homes too....

Comment: I drive W 6th and 7th Ave. every day, and have for many years. I am familiar with how long it used to take to traverse those streets and how long it takes now. I conservatively estimate I will spend at least 25 hours per year more on those streets now than I did prior to the EMX installation. Multiply that by the thousands of drivers who use those streets each day and the wasted hours are vast. Additionally, my car uses more fuel since it is running that much longer. Even if each EMX were used to capacity by people who would otherwise drive, the extra fuel used by everyone else who still must drive would dwarf any fuel savings attributable to EMX. The fender benders caused by the disappearing left lanes on 6th and serpentine lanes on 7th add to the external costs of this EMX boondoggle. And I am sure the extra walking distance between EMX stops thrills its senior citizen and disabled users. What a waste of $100 million to build it, plus the additional costs to everyone else.

Sprayed in its charge, the bear knocked me on my butt, growling and snarling in my face, waving its paw threateningly at my head (according to Keith Benner). 'Be Bear Aware', distributed by U.S. National Park Service, Forest Service, Fish & Wildlife, Department of the Interior, etc., advises bear spray for bear attacks. However, whenever there is a bear attack, wildlife officials respond with firearms--not just bear spray. ADN follow up article (to ours)--'Pepper Spray? We're just not permitted to have a reasonable and mature discussion about these things and none of our major federal parties seem inclined to change this.

Comment: It's one thing not to understand the Criminal Code; it's another not to understand a Globe and Mail comment.  Let me be more clear:

1.  In Canada, trespassing is a provincial regulatory offence, NOT a crime under the Criminal Code  (with the exception of one provision relating only to properties adjacent to dwelling places).   In Ontario, for instance, it's found in the Trespass to Property Act. 

2.  Break and Enter is a crime, but requires not only (a) the physical break and enter, but also (b) "intent to commit an indictable offence" once you're inside. Nothing in the article suggests the second requirement has been found.

Just going by the article, the tipsy Liberal staffer *may* have committed a provincial offence, although that's far from clear, based on the statute.  

And, who knows, further investigation may reveal that there was an unlawful purpose behind the entry, but nobody has that information now.

I hope that clears things up for the Globe comments legal experts.  ;-)

Comment: What rubbish!  Increase tanker traffic three-fold?  Not true.  But let's not focus on multipliers, because one tanker per year, if increased to one tanker every 6 months is a 100% increase . . . ooohhh, scary!  So let's examine real ship's numbers first, shall we?

BC has very low marine traffic density.  Juan de Fuca Strait; fewer than 11,000 transits by ocean going vessels each year.  By comparison, Dover Straits has 25% of world seaborne trade: 600 commercial vessels in transit or crossing daily.  The Strait of Malacca, between the coastlines of Indonesia, Malaysia & Singapore sees annual traffic of 64,000 ships; 21,000 container ships & 23,000 tankers. The Port of Rotterdam handles around 36,000 ships a year.  Canada’s busiest port, Vancouver, handles only 3,000 ships annually.  

Adding 300 more ships per year originating from Burrard Inlet to the 11,000 existing Juan de Fuca/Cape Flattery transits, is an increase of 02.7%.  Call it 3% - hardly a 7-fold increase, is it?

Comment: Yes, incoming radiation is cyclical and correlates directly with sunspot activity.  When sunspot activity slows, it gets cooler, and when it increases, it gets warmer ... totally independent of the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere.  Hence the cooling period from the late 1930's into the 1960's when sunspot activity slowed while the uptrend in CO2 concentration continued on a consistent upward path.  That's the period that NOAA kept adjusting its data on to try to make it disappear, because it contradicts their theory.

The problem is that you can't to anything about sunspot activity, so you chose a demon you think you can have an impact on and get paid for it.  Even though it isn't the problem.

Comment: More reasons to NOT speed up and rather slow down when it comes to climate risk mitigation policies that have been linked to flooding?:

http://www.cityfloodmap.com/2017/05/prime-minister-trudeau-makes-false.html

Engineers, hydrologists, watershed managers, hydraulic engineers/modellers can explain flooding by increased hydrologic stresses (more pavement and more runoff) - changing rainfall is not the driver at all:

http://www.cityfloodmap.com/2016/08/urbanization-and-runoff-explain.html

Historical land use development practices explain flooding, not changing climate and rain extremes - consider high risk developments like in Calgary right in the river floodway, or Gatineau with 75% of homes  in the "20 year floodplain", or Toronto island with flooding since the mid 1800's:

http://www.cityfloodmap.com/2017/09/toronto-island-flooding-2017-were-lake.html

2017 Lake Ontario levels were only 5 cm above previous maximum levels - long term land leases in a high risk zone were real issue.

Comment: "empirically hateful"

Empirical = 'by observation rather than by logic or theory' = subjective.

Most modern 'hate speech' is really just speech that someone disagrees with because they don't like the conclusions, and so you cannot separate their own personal dislike for the concepts from 'hate'.  I much prefer the legal standard, where you have to actually be looking to harm or incite harm against a people before it qualifies.  It keeps the waters less muddy and takes the job out of the mob, and puts it where it belongs with the police.  Making empiricism our standard really means that we're handing the keys to public discourse to some pretty thin-skinned people.

Comment: What Grey said was that if the Town ignored the plebiscite and approved the rezoning, the No side would likely fail in any action against it. While that might be true (for a variety of reasons), the converse is not. Were the Centre to pursue a Charter challenge against the Town, the outcome would undoubtedly turn on the proponent's ability to show that the vote was patently biased. Other than the uncorroborated musings of the mayor (hearsay), neither you nor Grey has thus far cited any such evidence.   

Indeed something the mayor did say undermines his own reported suspicion of bias. He said that if the entire town had been eligible to vote, he is confident it would have passed. Most rational people would infer from that comment that the motives of the 19 were not disqualifying from a Charter perspective...that is, they had other, legitimate reasons for saying no. Certainly the onus would be on Grey - were he representing the Centre - to demonstrate otherwise.

By 1965, there was a decisive shift in Catholic attitudes and presence in the struggle for racial justice. Comment: Remember this is not happening in a free market.  This is a corner where many (if not all) those who wish to borrow money are not well informed about the actual (absorbitant) cost. Kids are to turn in their phones at night, as nothing good happens after 9PM with teens and cell phones. We don't allow them to watch many of the popular movies, with terrible morals in them. This is called parenting. It is really hard to be a parent to your kids. It is necessary that you are first their parent, then their friend. Sometimes that means they might not like us for some time. We try our best, and yes, pray it all works out and they are productive, polite, responsible, successful adults. We know where they are at ALL times.

Comment: That’s an interesting question, HabFan410.  I’m not sure what to make of the reality of micro-aggressions.  Many people seem to think that it is an invented term that serves to promote a culture of victimhood.  Thus, people see the young black man who takes serious offence at a joke alluding to the history of slavery as overreacting.  “It’s just a joke; get over it; don’t be a victim,” people say.  The theory of micro aggression, as I understand it, says that constant exposure to such “jokes” has a cumulative effect on a person’s wellbeing.  Is that a real phenomenon?  I’m not sure.  I haven’t studied the issue.  But I have noted that some of the same people who ridicule the theory of micro aggression in minority groups tend to express sentiments of victimization concerning discussions of “white privilege.”  Many people seem to be saying, “I’m sick of hearing about the evils of racism.  Can we just shut up about it?”  Is that perhaps evidence of the reality of micro aggression?

Comment: Hi Joe, I covered that in another response, but you might not have seen it. Recap:

Contrary to what some seem to think, freedom to practice one's religion extends beyond choosing what to believe and/or where to worship, and also entails freedom from the state coercing you into violating your religious tenets.

The baker's position is that the unique consulting, designing, creating, delivery, setup, etc. involved with a wedding cake forces him to be a participant in an event he considers a mockery of a sacred rite (the marriage ceremony) as practiced in his religion.  This is arguably a greater (and Constitutional) harm than merely being offended. The wedding participation part is that to which he objects. He has otherwise NOT discriminated in the normal everyday conduct of business with the couple, so it may be difficult to say that his refusal on THIS issue was simply due to their being gay. 

The SC seems to think there is enough of a question here to warrant their hearing the case.

Comment: The Brits have done well, financially and otherwise, with their nationally-owned galleries and museums being free. Comment: I'm a professional (physician). In the process of unincorporating. There is a lot of exaggeration on both sides. I have done some pretty careful calculations....I save about $3000 - $5000/year via incorporation. I also pay ~$2500 extra in accounting/legal fees. The people who really lose on these changes are very high-priced specialists who income split with young adult children and a say-at-home spouse as well as the lawyers and accountants who have been carrying out the various schemes. Most primary care physicians will be surprised at how little they are impacted....While I do think some federal bureaucrats need a reality check (and changes to) their bloated benefits/pensions, physicians still have RRSPs, RESPS, TFSAs...one can save ~$36 000 a year using these, which if invested smartly e.g. ETFs will generate a very comfortable retirement and education paid that most Canadians don't enjoy....and if one still insists on a private corporation, there are still personal pension plans.

Comment: The CBC article is probably completely correct. In Ontario, only a percentage of tenants - those living in buildings built before a specified year in the 1990s (I believe 1991) - are protected under Ontario's "guideline" rent increase system, and even then they're only protected to a certain extent as AGIs can be applied to these tenants. As for turnover units, landlords can charge new tenants in any building whatever the market will bear as there is no protection against large increases in base entry rents charged to new tenants. There is no longer a "rent control" system in Ontario. Once a new tenant has lived in their apartments for a year their right to protection under the guideline system kicks into effect, provided they live in a building that qualifies. I believe that tenants who rent in newer condo buildings (a quickly expanding segment of the rental market) and rentals built after 1991 aren't protected at all under the current regime.

Comment: When I did Crow Pass in 2013, the water was above my waist. I had expected knee high water and wasn't prepared for how wide the crossing was. My two hiking partners and I teamed up with 2 other groups so there was 7 of us linking arms to do the crossing. It was going well until the dog of one of the other girls started getting swept away. She jumped for the dog and broke the chain. The one end of the chain started going down. It was pretty scary trying to regain balance when your feet are numb from the cold and there are large cobbles that move under your feet. In retrospect, I wouldn't cross it that high again but we had prepared for a long day hike not an overnighter. It is an epic hike but the river crossing was much more dangerous than I had imagined. Don't underestimate it and call the Eagle River Nature center to get River conditions before you go.

Comment: The second part of the process happens on Election Day. When the voters in each state cast votes for the Presidential candidate of their choice they are voting to select their state's Electors. The potential Electors' names may or may not appear on the ballot below the name of the Presidential candidates, depending on election procedures and ballot formats in each state. 
The winning Presidential candidate's slate of potential Electors are appointed as the state's Electors—except in Nebraska and Maine, which have proportional distribution of the Electors. In Nebraska and Maine, the state winner receives two Electors and the winner of each congressional district (who may be the same as the overall winner or a different candidate) receives one Elector. This system permits the Electors from Nebraska and Maine to be awarded to more than one candidate.

Comment: I'm no Constitutional expert, but I was under the impression that the Founders, operating with the same Enlightenment spirit that was to guide the French Revolution, specifically attempted to equate constitutional legitimacy with moral legitimacy in an effort to create a secular government that enshrined the basic values of the human spirit. My understanding, admittedly that of an outsider, is that the Founders wanted to keep religion at arm's length to inhibit the kinds of pressure to which European governments had been (and in some cases, continue to be) subject. I agree that the American people will expect Mr. Trump to exhibit a new moral fiber, but I'm not certain the drafters of the U.S. Constitution would have made MSW's distinction between constitutional and moral legitimacy -- or his assumption that moral legitimacy will coincide with his or Catholic values.

Comment: I was in school in Toronto in the 60s-70s as the only peanut allergic kid around - way before Epipens had been invented. My thoughts are this: allergic reactions without Epipens/ER departments can kill. Trying to exist in a protective peanut-free environment is dangerous because it provides false and temporary safety. Allow peanuts in schools and make sure the child carries an Epipen and that child and school staff know how to use it (it's really simple). Teach the child what to avoid - mistakes will happen - but that's what the Epipens are for. They work really well! There are peanuts everywhere, so learning early what a reaction is like and how to manage it.

Comment: Way too complicated.  The entire problem could be avoided by a much simpler mathematical formula.  Take the distance between the center line of your head (as you face the altar) and the center line of your neighbor's head (similarly measured).  Now divide by 5.  If your neighbor's hand reaches the 3/5 mark before yours even moves, assume he doesn't give a damn about your feelings.  Then move your hand quickly to the 2/5 mark, thus closing completely the distance between the mid-line of your head and the mid-line of his, and theoretically, the distance between your hand and his.   Now, take his offending hand, smile, and grip his hand until, instead of "Our Father," you hear "Oh, my God!"  Continue until the decibel level reaches 175 (the equivalent of a howitzer), and then smile, saying, " . . . and forgive us our trespasses."  He'll either transfer to a Franciscan parish or sit in the back from then on.

Comment: Reuters, as with other media, continues to snub the CPIH measure, which has been the Office of National Statistics’ headline measure of inflation, and is now used in generating its real wage estimates. Instead it still reports on the old CPI measures. If anyone is interested, and there is really no reason to be, the CPIH inflation rate was 2.6% in June, the same as the CPI rate, down from 2.7% in May, a little lower than the CPI rate. The CPIH is the UK CPI with an owner-occupied housing (OOH) component based on rental equivalence added to it, and a component for council taxes. The CPIH excluding council tax would have some limited value for decomposing the difference between the inflation rate for the CPI and for the household final consumption expenditure (HHFCE) deflator due to different treatments of OOH. Otherwise, it is essentially useless.

Comment: Keep in mind that Sweden (and Denmark, Finland, Norway and Iceland) has a lower corporate tax rate than Canada does.

Germany has a slightly higher corporate tax rate (~29% vs. ~26.5% in Canada) but provides substantial tax advantages for small and medium businesses.

European countries, in general, have very high VAT rates but their income taxes, particularly at the high-end, are usually comparable or lower than those in Canada, so a business owner in one of these "high tax" countries might actually be better off, tax-wise, than they would be in Canada.

Comment: The size of the budget balance is irrelevant for a country that issues its own currency.  Targeting the size of the deficit should never be an object of policy; the focus should be on adjusting government spending to ensure that the economy is continuously running at full employment.  If aggregate spending is too low, and it is right now and for the foreseeable future, the government should cut taxes and spend more, without regard for the budget outcome.  It's foolish to focus on financial outcomes when the federal government is not financially constrained.  Budget balancing as a principle of public finance for a currency issuing government is an obsolete relic of the gold standard era and robs society of a critical tool for advancing public purpose.

Comment: There seem to be two camps regarding this pipeline, and other prospective pipelines.  The first would hold that it is a necessity, a bringer of many jobs, a system that would allow us to export canadian goods in raw oil and bitumen around the world.  Both of these things would positively impact the economy.  The second holds that despite the short term benefits in form of jobs and a jump in gdp, we should not be allowing more pipelines to be built on principle.  I am of the second camp.  Global warming sure as hell isn't a myth, and despite the cynicism of people in my generation (I am a millenial after all) and the cynicism of the generation of my parents (i.e. babyboomers), it remains imperative that we fight climate change and the ways in which climate change is exacerbated.  It is our responsibility to halt oil pipelines from being built, full stop. It is our responsibility to force the government and by extension, corporations, to adopt green energy policies.

Is there that owre (over)  his French ragout,

On sic* (such) a dinner?

As feckless as a wither'd rash (rush),

His nieve (fist) a nit;
Thro bloody flood or field to dash,

The trembling earth resounds his tread,
Clap in his walie nieve (massive fist) a blade,

An legs an arms, an heads will sned (sever)

Comment: "Simply speaking, many Canadians accept the right of the individual to practise whatever faith she or he chooses on a personal level, but believe when it comes to the collective, religion has no place in Canadian democracy."

The author laments this development but to me it equates with social progress. My father spoke of the stifling role of religion in pre-WWII Ontario society, where communities were deeply divided on the basis of chauvinistic (Protestant vs Catholic) faith and one couldn't venture far beyond one's own faith or identity to find employment, socialize or (God forbid!) marry. WWII, where everybody came together in a common cause, was the equalizer, and after that, according to my father, the increasingly secular society that emerged was more harmonious, cohesive and equitable and offered greater freedom and dignity for everybody. Should this not be the goal in a diverse society? Unfortunately, the nature of religion is to divide. So keep it a private matter.

Comment: I don't think we live in different universes, just different centuries.
Why would I write letters to the people I care about... when I can have an ongoing conversation with them everytime I take a 5 minute break, for free ? That said, on the rare occasions an individual has sent me a letter in the last few years (usually overseas friends) I have always gotten it.
I can't speak for KZN but the postal service in the Western Cape has been perfectly adequate.

As for the claim about good mail service = good government... again, not in THIS century. Heck, but for institutional inertia the BEST governments today wouldn't have postal services at all anymore.
I am generally in favor of public services, especially when it can provide a free alternative for the poor, even if that alternative is lower quality. The post office however has outlived it's usefulness. It was a great invention that served us well for 2000 years. But like the horse cart, it's time has passed.

Comment: That's fairly easy. Judges are independent but also do what they have been asked to do; they give fair hearings and render carefully thought out judgments. 

We are not talking about what the Senate has been asked to do by this particular government, although this government is driving the change. We are discussing what the Senate is being asked to do as an institution, regardless of which party controls the House of Commons. As Mr. Harder construes it, the Senate in its role as the chamber of sober second thought is primarily advisory. House of Commons bills go to the Senate, which tidies them up, makes detail changes, and if it appears that the House has acted in a burst of excessive and unwise enthusiasm, delays until the fervor dies down. It is not the job of the Senate to force change, but rather to push the House of Commons to rethink.

Comment: If a carbon tax is inevitable (not convinced yet), the only credible plan I have seen is Michael Chong's federal revenue neutral tax.  The major differences are the significant income and business tax cuts in advance of a gradually rising carbon tax, and corresponding cuts to other expensive federal green programs to help to pay for it.  I.e. it is a truly market-driven approach.  

Another reasonable approach is Erin O'Toole's proposed industrial incentive program for reducing emissions.

Trudeau's approach (like Wynne or Notley) is excessively expensive, as it layers on another tax on top of already high income taxes, and actually augments government overhead (both the existing green funding programs and net new overhead to sort out McKenna's unnecessarily complex carbon plan).  

Sadly, Chong is a long shot in the May 27 leadership race, and if a far right candidate like Bernier is their new leader, we may well be at the mercy of Trudeau's tax and spend ways for another 6 years.

Comment: I like these "questions for reflection" and growth from Fr Francis Fernandez, from In Conversation with God:

"- What is the true motivation of my actions? 
- What is my heart really set upon?
- Have I really tried to be detached from earthly goods, or on the contrary, do I suffer and complain when I am short of something?
- How quick am I to react against the slightest incitement to self-seeking and ease, promoted very often by the advertisements of the consumer society? 
-Am I sparing in my personal needs, do I put curbs on my extravagance, do I avoid frivolous and unnecessary purchases?
- Do I cheerfully accept whatever inconveniences me and the lack of means at my disposal? 
- Am I generous in giving alms to those who are in much worse circumstances? 
- Do I contribute to the support of good causes, depriving myself of things I would like to have...?

Only in this way will we live with the joy and freedom necessary if we are to be disciples of our Lord in the midst of the world."

Comment: I wouldn't be so quick to assume it's the fault of the French immersion. My kid is in the regular English program, grade 2.  I send him to extra math class because I find what he learns at school is scattershot.  The homework I see does not have practice questions in gradually increasing order of difficulty.  It jumps around, and doesn't reinforce what he's learned.  As a mathematician, I'm regularly aghast at the material he brings home.

In contrast, at the extra-curricular math, each week they have: 
- Drills in addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.  The point of the drills is fluency.
- And "word problems".  They learn 1 new type of word problem about every 3 weeks, and practice about 6 questions a week.  They also periodically review what they've learned this year.  

I've seen a huge change in attitude since he started taking these classes.  In September, he would say "I hate math, it's hard".  Now he says "Of course I'm good at math, it's easy".

Comment: I'm currently taking a Business Ethics course at the university.  We primarily look at case studies about major companies and corporations.  Business ethics is definitely an oxymoron.

Looking at the the product warranty I noticed that in Canada the product is under warranty for FIVE years but only ONE year in the U.S.  

Not satisfied, I contacted Congressman Young's D.C. office.  The congressman is fully supportive of the market place determining what we live with in our daily lives.  You don't like it, don't buy it, is the motto in Don's DC office. We can't be burdening business with more regulations.

The problem is, we Alaskans are paying the price in lax regulatory oversight or guidance. 
Why do Canadians receive a five year warranty while we Alaskans receive a one year warranty.  Because their politicians care.

They can easily unlock doors and leave the house at any time especially at night since kids on the spectrum wake up at all hours of the night and are fully alert when they do. They have a tendency to bolt or wander for hours without any sense of danger or awareness just as an elderly person with dementia might do. As the author stated, young kids with ASD are utterly fascinated by water and will jump in without a thought.  Explaining the danger does not work since most have no real concept of what danger is. One kid in 68 has autism.

-speed
-distraction

The problem is that existing penalties simply are not being imposed stringently enough.  An impaired driver needs time and solitude to consider the error of their ways. Comment: If the defence does not know how the evidence was obtained, they cannot properly probe its authenticity and accuracy. If, for instance, the technique used can be shown to sometimes err in identifying the particular telephone from which a given message originates, that raises reasonable doubts about whether the right person is accused of sending that message. A simple assertion by police that they used undisclosed techniques to intercept messages originating from a particular phone, or passing between a particular pair of phones,  without disclosure of the technique used, does not allow the defence to make full answer and defence and so is unacceptable.

Comment: Dear G&M editors,

No 'rights' or 'freedoms' are absolute.  Freedom of speech is not for example.
Neither is freedom of religion.  Of course people are free to practice their religion in their own way privately.  But if the 'customs' of that religion conflict with others' rights and freedoms then there has to be some compromise.  That is in fact why we have a legal system, to deal with competing rights.
I have the right to send my children to a weapon-free learning environment.  Wearing a knife is a weapon, whatever its called. Full stop.
I have the right to see and identify with whom I am dealing.  Concealing identity makes fraud much easier.
Canadians are open minded and are ready to compromise, so should new Canadians. "Reasonable accommodation" not absolute submission to unacceptable practices, religious or not.

Comment: I own a 2012 Mazda 3 that I bought used at 80K a couple of years ago. Manual tranny, it's most engaging car I've ever owned, simply beautiful to drive. There are sportier, more luxurious rides out there but I'd challenge anyone to find one that comes close to this car for the price. Best of all, it has enough tech and features for me (Bluetooth, traction control, some steering wheel controls, heated seats) while keeping the rest of the cockpit thoughtfully simple and clean. Now at 170K I haven't had any issues with it at all and no rust. I hope Mazda can survive in the land of the giant automakers, that will indeed be their biggest challenge.

Comment: Levels of classification for American Intelligence 
Confidential: Information that reasonably could be expected to cause damage to the national security if disclosed to unauthorised sources. Most military personnelhave this level of clearance. 

Secret: The same wording in the first sentence above, except it substitutes serious damage. 

Top Secret: Again, the same wording except to substitute exceptionally grave damage. 

Codeword: Adds a second level of clearance to Top Secret,so that only those cleared with the codeword can see it. Administered by the CIA. The material discussed by Mr Trump with the Russians was under a codeword, sources told the Washington Post.

Comment: This has been documented quite extensively & you can look up a full picture quite easily, but in a nutshell - the Metis descended from a relatively small number of Indigenous women who were partnered with Euro men early-mid 1700s. You cannot assume every or most forever then on somehow 'married' another white man. In fact, there may not have been another 'white man/woman' ever in  many families. 

These original Metis moved to  western areas - Red River/now Winnipeg and throughout the prairies, some groups to Quebec. These women's descendants were very well-documented and along with identifying as Metis, the Metis Nation Assns require descendants to provide records that show those connections which these societies will research for authenticity before accepting members into the Metis Nation. 

If  you're of mixed ethnicity, you merely claim your nations, as in half Scot, half Mohawk or whatever combination, but Metis is Metis Nation.

Comment: "Was I lost and now am found? Who came looking for me?"

I would think it might have been The Hound Of Heaven:

"Nicholson & Lee, eds.  The Oxford Book of English Mystical Verse. 1917.
  
239. The Hound of Heaven
By Francis Thompson  (1859–1907)
http://www.bartleby.com/236/239.html
  
I FLED Him, down the nights and down the days;	
  I fled Him, down the arches of the years;	
I fled Him, down the labyrinthine ways	
    Of my own mind; and in the mist of tears	
I hid from Him, and under running laughter.	        
      Up vistaed hopes I sped;	
      And shot, precipitated,	
Adown Titanic glooms of chasmèd fears,	
  From those strong Feet that followed, followed after.	
      But with unhurrying chase,	       
      And unperturbèd pace,	
Deliberate speed, majestic instancy,	
      They beat—and a Voice beat	
      More instant than the Feet—	
‘All things betray thee, who betrayest Me.’"

There are several more versus worth reading.

Comment: After a blood bath with Nortel in 2000/2001, I became a smaller, more cautious market speculator. 

I decided to look not only at specific companies and stocks but also at global economic and market trends and at the capacity of governments to help provide environments conducive to mid and long term growth and prosperity.

From the latter perspective, looking at the Trudeau and Trump cabinet teams  and their financial track records and reputations and also at the way our lot is piling up massive, unending deficits, spending like drunken sailors and now warring with SB,  I cannot take the Canadian government seriously as sound macro-economic and public finances managers.

So I also find it difficult to have confidence in the Canadian equity market and prefer to invest south of the border where people with actual track records, reputations and expertise in these matters now serve in senior government roles.

Perhaps others feeling the same way has helped drag down the TSE.

Comment: The benchmark price was up over the year by 17.6% for condos, 10.7% for townhouses and only 1.4% for single-detached homes. So one can understand why the May 2017 annual inflation rate for BC homeowners’ replacement cost was only 4.5%. Although there are other factors, the big one would be that the new housing price index for dwellings excludes apartment condos altogether and is over-weighted within houses towards single-detached dwellings. This is the series from which the replacement cost CPI gets its dwelling price data. Consequently inflation is badly underestimated for BC homeowners. If he were doing his job properly, this is a defect that Bank of Canada Governor Poloz would bring up at every press conference, but he is missing in action.

Comment: Progress on environmental improvement takes time because of the lifetime of products.  The need for regulations was clear before the Nixon administration where agencies with regulations were put into place during the Nixon and Carter administrations that had their goals been followed would have resulted in significant improvement in environmental quality by now.
The time to design a product with improved efficiencies will take years but the product lifetimes are frequently measured in decades so if less efficient products are introduced it will be decades before there will be replacement or upgrade. The weakening of standards in the Reagan administration and failure to improvement in later administrations has resulted in many health issues in those years were the costs of that failure was paid by individuals rather than possible (though unlikely) corporate interests.

Comment: What is it about Albertans? Is there something about a world-wide oil industry collapse that they don't get? 

Global oil prices are down. Global demand is down. Bitumen is worth far less than crude oil. Yet despite these incontrovertible facts, Albertans think a pipeline to the coast will solve their problems. All that'll do is increase the supply glut, therefore reducing prices further. Nobody, not even China, is ever going to pay Brent prices for bitumen. 

Alberta's problems go far beyond access to tidewater. Demand is down, remember? Oil is a sunset industry. Low crude prices have taken a toll on Exxon profits, which fell from US$32.5 billion  in 2014 to $16.2 billion in 2015 to $7.8 billion in 2016 (and will decline again in 2017). Diversify!

Alberta thinks that we in BC should sacrifice our environment and our economy? Alberta lost a lot of tarsands jobs but will probably never get them back even with a pipeline. We stand to lose far more - much of it irreplaceable.

Comment: The goal of light rail is not to fix or even ease congestion. That is not a possible goal. No matter how much roadway/highway we have, people will fill it and we will have congestion. That is just how any functioning city works. The only way in the history of the automobile that traffic has been eased is through economic downturn. People work less, go out less, shop less and therefore they drive less.

The purpose of Light rail is to provide options for people to get around without sitting in congestion. 95% of the new people to the region who commute to downtown Seattle are using transit to get to/from work. If we didn't have decent transit, Seattle would not have been able to effectively grow as much as it has.

There are still expected to be, barring a large economic downturn in multiple industries, hundreds of thousands more people moving her over next decades. Making transit better is how you attract people who will use transit. Shifting existing residents mode of transpo is hard.

Comment: Realistically, however, foreign income gets a pretty high exemption, and places like Canada also enjoy a tax reciprocity agreement with the US. What does this mean? 

If I were working in Canada right now, I would have to earn 124 thousand CAD before I have to worry about paying US taxes. This is in addition to my US personal exemption and all the other tax accounting tricks I have to deal with. With my wife in the mix, that becomes 248k CAD, and that number goes up every year indexed to inflation. That's income that the US will not count as income at all for me. If I get lucky enough to earn, say, 258kCAD (210kUSD at current exchange rates), then I'll subtract the 202k USD exemption from the 210k USD income and then pay an awesomely amazing...$800 in US taxes, assuming Canada's tax reciprocity agreement with the US doesn't eat those away. Make no mistake. Living in Canada means I'll pay less US taxes than if I stayed here. But I still get to vote! That was my point. :3

Comment: Hawaii has done a lot of work in regards to assessing our high school athletes; however, there is still a lot of work to do in supporting our students as there is nothing in place to help those who suffer concussions outside of high school athletics. Current protocol requires a school athletic trainer (for some reason, a physician's note will not suffice) to do an assessment, but does not specify a timeline.....resulting in unfair treatment for someone with a traumatic brain injury. For example: a student who is a victim of a car accident or physical assault is not eligible to receive accommodations such as extended test time unless that student is classified as needing special education services. Students could have their grades suffer as a result of missed opportunities, directly impacting their grade point averages and, subsequently, their post-secondary educational options. Please support House Concurrent Resolution 4 when it is heard in the legislature. Our children need it!!!

Comment: If I had a billion dollars today -here's what I would do to start getting there. I would invest it all in a safe but decentish investment for a year, lets say earning 10% (we'll ignore inflation for now to make the math simple - but it's easy to factor in - and there are plenty of somewhat similar funds like the Nobel prize fund that show the basic premise can work).
Now I have one million in profit. Take 500-thousand of that and give it 50 poor people ten-thousand rand each, they can do whatever the hell they want with it. I don't care.
Reinvest the one billion and the other 500-thousand. Assuming the same percentage growth, I however achieved a compound interest effect (by adding half the profit to the principle). So next year maybe "half the profits" is a bit more. Now I give the same 50 people their ten-thousand again, and also give ten thousand to two other people. 
Repeat - within a few years I am giving every poor person in SA 10K a year. In a few decades. Everybody.

Comment: "You can protest outside of the stadium and off the sports pages, and I respect your right to do it. Please don't do it inside the stadium or here."

So you're fine with individuals exercising their right to protest, as long as it's done on terms that you personally agree with? That's an extremely hypocritical and, I must say, rather un-American stance to an inherently American practice. Americans have been protesting overreaches and abuses by government far longer than they've been singing the national anthem. Attempts to limit protest and free speech under the guise of "rules" are the exact sort of things our country was created to protect us against.

I'm not a huge fan of the kneeling, but it's not disrespectful. People kneel while praying and in church, they kneel before the Queen, they kneel when proposing marriage. "Disrespectful" would be a player sitting down and putting his feet up during the anthem, checking his phone or chatting up a cheerleader or something like that.

Seán Stokes

Comment: Our drug laws have cost billions of dollars, incarcerated millions of people, massively empowered the government relative to the citizenry, and failed to significantly curtail drug use and abuse.  They aren't working.  The author of this article fails to recognize the debacle that has transpired over the last half century.

Minor adjustments here and there will not fix what is wrong.  You can't make something that doesn't work somehow work better with small changes, that only makes it do a better job of not working.  We need a complete overhaul.  That cannot happen without first eliminating the Controlled Substances Act and trying an entirely different approach.  

We overhauled welfare, and it was a justified overhaul.  It was not, however, as justified as the need to overhaul our drug laws.  Welfare never cost this country what our drug laws.  Not even close.  It's time to end drug laws as we know them.

Comment: Unable to agree on any particular method for selecting presidential electors, the Founding Fathers left the choice of method exclusively to the states in Article II, Section 1
“Each State shall appoint, in such Manner as the Legislature thereof may direct, a Number of Electors….”  
The U.S. Supreme Court has repeatedly characterized the authority of the state legislatures over the manner of awarding their electoral votes as "plenary" and "exclusive." 

The constitutional wording does not encourage, discourage, require, or prohibit the use of any particular method for awarding a state's electoral votes.
	
States have the responsibility and constitutional power to make all of their voters relevant in every presidential election and beyond.  Now, 38 states, of all sizes, and their voters, because they vote predictably, are politically irrelevant in presidential elections.

Comment: There is no way that a corporation will absorb these costs.

Corporations selling to consumers may increase prices at groceries, utilities, department and home improvement stores, car dealers, etc. Nothing stopping any of them from adding a 2.5% surcharge on all purchases to cover the tax, or burying the cost with increased prices.

Suppliers to small businesses in Oregon will pass this tax on at each level of the supply chain. This will multiply the effective tax, hurting the smallest businesses the most, and the largest ones the least.

There are several hundred small businesses lending their support. Each  may want to talk to their tax accountants and suppliers to better understand how this tax might indirectly affect their costs, even if they are well below $25M in Oregon sales.

This 2.5% tax surcharge is in addition to any state income tax already due.

The measure implies that this money will go to education, healthcare, and senior services. It all goes to the general fund.

Comment: The DP article stated Taylor testified that her bodyguard, Greg Dent, standing nearby, " . . . saw the move (Mueller lifting up Taylor's dress) from where he (Dent) was standing, diagonally behind her . . . ." Dent, according to Taylor, saw Mueller lift her skirt? How could Swift's testimony be true? Think about it. Her bodyguard sees a man lift her skirt, and the bodyguard does nothing? He does not even inquire about what happened? Here's the question: Are bodyguards trained to ignore the action of a relative stranger lifting the skirt of their client, someone they are trained to protect? I think not. Bodyguards are supposed to be aware of what's going on to the client. This makes me believe that Taylor either embellished or lied about Dent being a witness to the skirt lift. If so, what else is she fabricating?

Comment: We already have three examples of what single payer would be like if it came about: VA medical system, Medicaid, and Medicare.
1. VA type system, with thousands dying waiting for poor care while the administrators declare bonuses for themselves.
2. Medicaid, with poor care given in health clinics.
3. Medicare, which most doctors don't accept because of the low payments and which has to be supplemented with private insurance.
So which of these sterling example would you like to be forced upon the whole country?

Comment: Anchorage needs to diversify it's tax/revenue base, and the only sensible solution is a sales tax that directly offsets property taxes.  It is unwise to rely on one revenue source in such a commodity-driven economy as Alaska's, especially when a lot of sales $$ flow through the state from visitors, leaving a potential source of revenue untapped.  If we don't diversify, and property values decrease, sure you can just raise the mill rate, but at some point that scenario has an end game because property owners aren't getting the same level of benefit out of ownership they were before, but you're asking them to continue to pay the same level of tax.  I can, to a limited extent, adjust my consumption and control my sales taxes.  I can't liquidate positions in real estate easily at all to control my property taxes.

Comment: Social Security was a good idea and had a sound footing.  What is present today is not sustainable and needs changing.  The articles on funding for Social Security could and should be encouraged.  Most of the articles referring to depletion of money in 2028 and longer do not state that the funding includes cashing in and using the IOU’s from the US Treasury (trillions).  Where is that money coming from?  Probably the Federal Reserve system buying more Treasury bonds..and that equals more dilution of our money.   When administering a system that impacts 350+ million people, the “best way” is not always chosen as much as some particular way to keep it running- a way that keeps govt workers employed and politicians from being defensive.

Comment: Did the author read the R/G Feb 7th editorial - Urban condescension amplifies rural protest?  He is a classic example of the "self-righteous and dismissive tone.  We in urban Oregon know better and are more sophisticated than you rural hicks. "  Moving these hard working families of the Federal range lands for them to "Get on with New Lives" is extremely heartless and ill founded.  These hard working ranchers care for these expansive lands and are the core of the rural communities.   Yes recreation activities have been and will continue to be an important part of the rural economy but these core citizens that are there all year long tending these vast lands serve as the foundation of these communities.  In my retirement I have learned how special eastern Oregon is.  And what is most impressive is the honest hard working you people you meet over there.   We should treasure what they provide to Oregon rather than urge them to move on to new lives.

Chris Cadwell
